explanation: OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET - Macro (or inline wrapper) used with the expression '*token'. Must inspect its expansion to ensure it does not assign to the parameter variable 'token' itself (or otherwise use the token identifier in a way that writes to the caller's parameter). If the macro evaluates/assigns the passed expression, that might modify the object pointed to (permitted) but must not reassign the parameter variable. OS_ObjectIndexFromToken - Appears in the call graph and may be used by the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET implementation. Check its prototype/implementation to confirm it does not take/modify the address of the caller's parameter(s) (e.g. by accepting a pointer to token) or otherwise reassign the parameter variable. OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime - Called with 'timeout' and '&ts'. Verify its prototype/implementation to ensure it does not take a pointer to 'timeout' (which could allow modifying the caller's parameter variable) or perform any hidden writes to the function parameters. OSAL_SIZE_C - Macro used when writing '*size_copied = OSAL_SIZE_C(...)'. Check its definition for side effects or parameter evaluation that could modify the local parameter variable 'size_copied' (e.g. if it expands in a way that assigns to its argument). mq_receive - System call used with 'data' and other args. Confirm its prototype (msg buffer parameter is passed by value as a pointer) to verify it cannot modify the pointer variable 'data' in the caller (only the pointed-to memory). mq_timedreceive - Same reasoning as mq_receive: examine the prototype to ensure it does not accept a pointer-to-pointer or otherwise allow modification of the local parameter variable. These symbols are needed to rule out any hidden or indirect writes to the function parameters (token, data, size, size_copied, timeout) that would violate the MISRA rule (parameter reassignment).
